questions.question: The party invitations ………………………. out.
questions.description: We use the present perfect tense to simply give news of recent events.

questions.question: The invention of the space rocket …………………….. many years.
questions.description: The simple past is the most normal tense for talking about finished events in the past.

questions.question: Alexander Graham Bell ……………………… the telephone.
questions.description: The simple past is the most normal tense for talking about finished events in the past.

questions.question: Saint Patrick ……………………….. Christianity to the Irish.
questions.description: The simple past is the most normal tense for talking about finished events in the past.

questions.question: Fairy tales ………………………….. most children.
questions.description: We use the present simple to talk about facts, general truths and habits.

questions.question: He ……………………….. to 90 days in jail.
questions.description: We need a passive verb here because the subject is not the doer of the action.

questions.question: She …………………………. with joy upon the birth of her grandchild.
questions.description: We need a passive verb here because the subject is not the doer of the action. Instead, something happened to the subject.

questions.question: How did you know I ……………………….. be there?
questions.description: When the verb in the main clause is in the past tense, we will need a past tense in the subordinate clause as well.

questions.question: He wanted to visit the land his father ……………………… from.
questions.description: When the verb in the main clause is in the past tense, we will need a past tense in the subordinate clause as well.

questions.question: Lately I ………………………… making my own clothes.
questions.description: We use the present perfect to talk about recent events.

questions.question: ……………………….. the packages on the table.
questions.description: To lay something is to place it somewhere.

questions.question: Which route ................................. I take to Denver?
questions.description: The simple present is the tense used to ask for or give directions.
